utterance: Well?
speaker: Mr. Ford

speaker: Johnny Filgee

speaker: Mr. Ford

jest his foolishness; he oughter be licked.

utterance:
Jimmy Snyder-he seed suthin'.
Ask
him!
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: Tige ith got thix,
speaker: Johnny Filgee

utterance: Come, Jimmy
speaker: Mr. Ford

Seed a black b'ar comin' outer Daves'
woods, Nigh to me ez
you be. 'N big ez a hoss; 'n snarlin'! 'n
-snappin'!-like gosh! Kem along — ker
-clump torords me. Reckoned he'd skeer

speaker: Jimmy Snyder

utterance:
Cressy McKinstry came home from
Sacramento. Mrs. McKinstry told mother
she's comin' back here to school.
speaker: Octavia Dean

utterance:
Tige, ith got thix pupths
mothly yaller.
speaker: Johnny Filgee

utterance: Books!
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
I thought Miss Mc-
Kinstry had been married by this time
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Oh no! dear no! - not that.
speaker: Octavia Dean

utterance: So it would seem
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: I reckon she never kalkilated to, either,
speaker: Octavia Dean

utterance: Indeed!
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
No-she was just funning with Seth
Davis-that's all.
speaker: Octavia Dean

utterance: Funning with him?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Yes, sir. Kinder foolin' him, you know.
speaker: Octavia Dean

utterance: Kinder foolin' him!
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
Crethy M'Kinthry
likth teacher
speaker: Johnny Filgee

utterance:
I reckoned, that is I allowed - I
-orter say that I'd find ye alone at this
time. Ye gin'rally are, ye know. It's a
nice, soothin', restful, stoodious time, when
a man kin, so to speak, run back on his ed-
dication and think of all he ever knowed.
Ye're jist like me, and ye see I sorter spotted
your ways to onct.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
Then why did you come here this morn-
ing and disturb the school?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
That's so, I sorter slipped up thar,
did n't I? You see I did n't allow to
come in then, but on'y to hang round a
leetle and kinder get used to it, and it to
me.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance: Used to what?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
I reckon ye ain't usin' Dobell's 'Rithme-
tic here?
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance: No
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
That's bad. 'Pears to be played out-
that Dobell feller. I was brought up on
Dobell. And Parsings' Grammar? Ye
don't seem to be a using Parsings' Grammar
either?
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance: No
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
And I reckon you'd be saying the same
of Jones' 'Stronomy and Algebry? Things
hev changed. You've got all the new style
here, For a man ez wos brought up on
Parsings, Dobell, and Jones, thar don't ap-
pear to be much show nowadays.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
Ef you'd had them books which you
have n't- I had it in my mind to ask you
suthen'. I had an idea of of sort of re-
viewing my eddication. Kinder going over
the old books agin-jist to pass the time.
Sorter running in yer arter school hours and
doin' a little practisin', eh? You looking
on me as an extry scholar and I payin' ye
as sich but keepin' it 'twixt ourselves, you
know — just for a pastime, eh?
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
Them jay birds out there is mighty
peart, coming right up to the school-house!
I reckon they think it sort o' restful too.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
But if you really mean it, could n't you
use these books, Uncle Ben? I dare say there's little
difference the principle is the same, you
know.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
Certingly. The
principle 's all there.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
And as to writing, for instance, you
know any copy-book will do.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
They're mighty bold — them jays, They don't seem
to be afeared of nothing, do they?
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
I tell
you what, Uncle Ben, the only
thing for you to do is to just throw over
Dobell and Parsons and Jones and the old
quill pen that I see you 're accustomed to,
and start in fresh as if you I'd never known
them. Forget 'em all, you know. It will
be mighty hard of course to do that, but
you must do it.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
That's so, that's me! Why, that's
jest what I was sayin' to Roop
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
Then you've already been talking about
it? I thought you wanted it kept secret?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
Well, yes. But you see I sorter agreed with
Roop Filgee that if you took to my ideas and
did n't object, I'd give him two bits every
time he'd kem here and help me of an arter-
noon when you was away and kinder stand
guard around the school-house, you know,
so as to keep the fellows off. And Roop's
mighty sharp for a boy, ye know.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
But could n't you do this more
securely and easily in your own house? I
might lend you the books, you know, and
come to you twice a week.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
It would n't be exactly the same kind o'
game to me an' Roop, You see thar's the idea o' the school-house,
ye know, and the restfulness and the quiet,
and the gen❜ral air o' study. And the boys
around town ez would n't think nothin' o'
trapsen' into my cabin if they spotted what
I was up to thar, would never dream o' hunt-
ing me here.
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
Very well, let it be
here then.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
After thanking you, Mr. Ford, ef you'll jest kinder
signify, you know, what you consider a
fair
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance:
You 're very welcome, and as I can only permit this sort of thing
gratuitously, you'd better not let me know
that you propose giving anything even to
Rupert.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
Then you reckon, that
I'd better jest chuck them Dobell fellers
overboard?
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance: I certainly should
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
And sorter waltz in fresh, like one o'
them children?
speaker: Uncle Ben Dabney

utterance: Like a child
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
There! don't flop!
And don't you, go on
breathing over my head like that. If there's
anything I hate it 's having a girl breathing
round me. Yes, you were!
Yes, you were! I felt it in
my hair. And you too-you're always
snoopin' and snoodgin'. Oh, yes, you want
to know why I've got an extry copy-book
and another 'Rithmetic, Miss Curiosity.
Well, what would you give to know? Want
to see if they're pretty No, they ain't pretty.
That's all you girls think about what's
pretty and what 's curious! Quit now!
Come! Don't ye see teacher lookin' at
you? Ain't you ashamed?
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance:
I've told Uncle Ben that you might help
him here after school hours. You may therefore
omit your writing exercise in the morning
and do it in the afternoon.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
And if
it would be all the same to you, sir, you might sorter give out
in school that I was to be kept in.
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: I'm afraid that would hardly do
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
But why? So ez to keep
them darned girls from foolin' round me and
followin' me back here.
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: We will attend to that
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance:
I suppose your father knows
that you are to receive money for this?
And he does n't object?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: He! Oh no! You need n't mind him.
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: Very well
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: I reckon I can go on where I left off?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: For the present.
speaker: the master

utterance: I have had no intimation yet from your father or mother that you were coming back to school again. But I suppose they have decided upon your return?
speaker: the master

utterance: I reckon paw and maw ain't no objection. Maw did offer to come yer and see you, but I told her she need n't bother.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Then I am to understand that this is a permanent thing?
speaker: the master

utterance: What's that?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Am I to understand that you intend coming regularly to school? or is this merely an arrango-ment for a few days -– until
speaker: the master

utterance: Oh, you mean that. Oh, that's broke off. Yes, that's over three weeks ago.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: And Seth Davis does he intend re-turning too?
speaker: the master

utterance: He! I reckon not much! S'long's I'm here, at least.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: So that's all?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the master

utterance: Kin I go now?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the master

utterance: Been quite well?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Yes thank you.
speaker: the master

utterance: You're lookin' right peart.'
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Is Cressy McKinstry comin' reg'lar, Mr. Ford?
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: She is.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Why?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: It's mighty rough, jest ez a feller reckons he's got quit of her and her jackass bo', to hev her prancin' back inter school agin, and rigged out like ez if she 'd been to a fire in a milliner's shop.
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: You should n't allow your personal dis-likes, Rupert, to provoke you to speak of a fellow-scholar in that way - and a young lady, too.
speaker: the master

utterance: The woods is full o' sich feller-scholars and sich young ladies, if yer keer to go a gunning for 'em. Ef I'd known she was comin' back I'd
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: What?
speaker: the master

utterance: I'd hev played hookey till she left school agin! It mout n't hev bin so long, neither.
speaker: Rupert Filgee

utterance: That will do. For the present you'll attend to your duty and try to make Uncle Ben see you 're something more than a foolish, preju-diced school-boy, or, he and I may both repent our agreement. Let me have a good account of you both when I return.
speaker: the master

utterance: Yer's that dared hound agin!
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: I beg your pardon, but I found the door open and I fol-lowed the dog.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: That's just one of, his pizenous tricks, On'y last week he let in a China-man, and in the natural hustlin' that follered he managed to help himself outer the pork bar'l. There ain't no shade o' cussedness that or nary hound in't up to.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: Now that you're here, set ye right down and make yourself to home. My men folks are all out o' door, but some of 'em's sure to happen in soon for suthin'; that day ain't yet created that they don't come huntin' up Mammy McKinstry every five minutes for this thing or that.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: Hiram allowed to go over to the school-house and see you this mornin', but I reckon ez how he had to look up stock on the river. The cattle are that wild this time o' year, huntin' water, and hangin' round the tules, that my men are nigh worrited out o' their butes with 'em. Hank and Jim ain't been off their mustangs since sun up, and Hiram, what with partrollen' the West Boundary all night, watchin' stakes whar them low down Harrisons hev been trespassin' has n't put his feet to the ground in fourteen hours. Mebbee you noticed Hiram ez you kem along? Ef so, ye did n't remember what kind o' shootin' irons he had with him? I see his rifle over yon. Like ez not he 'z only got his six-shooter, and them Har-risons are mean enough to lay for him at long range. But, I s'pose Cressy came all right.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: Yes.
speaker: the master

utterance: I reckon she looked so. She allowed to do herself credit in one of them new store gownds that she got at Sacramento. At least that's what some of our men said. Late years, I ain't kept tech with the fash-ions myself.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: She seemed well prepared in her les-sons, but am I to understand that she is coming regularly to school that she is now perfectly free to give her entire attention to her studies that that - her engagement is broken off?
speaker: the master

utterance: Why, did n't she tell ye?
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: She certainly did, but
speaker: the master

utterance: Ef she said so, she oughter know, and you kin tie to what she says.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: But as I'm responsible to parents and not to scholars for the discipline of my school, I thought it my duty to hear it from you.
speaker: the master

utterance: That's so; then I reckon you'd better see Hiram. That ar' Seth Davis engagement was a matter of hern and her father's, and not in my line. I 'spose that Hiram nat'-rally allows to set the thing square to you and inquirin' friends.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: I hope you understand, that my reason for inquiring about the permanency of your daughter's attendance was simply because it might be necessary to arrange her studies in a way more suitable to her years; perhaps even to suggest to you that a young ladies' seminary might be more satisfactory
speaker: the master

utterance: Sartain, sartain. You'd better speak to Hiram about it. On'y, ez he's got now sorter set and pinted towards your school, and is a trifle worrited with stock and them Harrisons, ye might tech it lightly. He oughter be along yer now. I can't think what keeps him.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: O Cressy!
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: O Maw!
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Howdy?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Cressy, Dad's gone and left his Sharps' yer, d' ye mind takin' it along to meet him, afore he passes the Boundary corner. Ye might tell him the teacher's yer, wantin' to see him.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: One moment. Let me take it. It's all on my way back to school and I'll meet him.
speaker: the master

utterance: No, Mr. Ford, Ye'd better not mix yourself up with these yer doin's. Ye've no call to do it, and Cressy has; it's all in the family. But it's outer your line, and them Harri-son whelps go to your school. Fancy the teacher takin' weppins betwixt and be-tween!
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: It 's fitter work for the teacher than for one of his scholars, and a young lady at that. It's quite safe with me, and I promise I shall deliver it into Mr. McKinstry's hands and none other.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Perhaps it would n't be ez likely to be gin'rally noticed ez it would if one of us carried it.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: You're quite right, So I'll say good-afternoon, and try and find your husband.
speaker: the master

utterance: Ye 'll like a drink afore ye go, I clean forgot my manners. Cressy, fetch out that demijohn.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: Not for me, thank you.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Oh, I see you 're temperance, nat'-rally.
speaker: Mrs. McKinstry

utterance: Hardly that, I follow no rule, I drink sometimes but not to-day.
speaker: the master

utterance: Don't you see, Maw, Teacher drinks sometimes, but he don't use whiskey. That's all.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: What did Maw say to yer about seein' me just now?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: I don't understand you.
speaker: the master

utterance: To your seein' me and Joe Masters on the trail?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: She said nothing.
speaker: the master

utterance: Humph.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: What was it you told her about it?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Nothing.
speaker: the master

utterance: Then you did n't see us?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: I saw you with some one - I don't know whom.
speaker: the master

utterance: And you did n't tell Maw?
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: I did not. It was none of my busi-ness.
speaker: the master

utterance: That Joe Masters is the conceitedest fellow goin'. I told him you could see his foolishness.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Ah, indeed.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Maw could n't quite hitch on to your not drinkin'. She reckons you're like everybody else about yer. That's where she slips up on you. And everybody else, I kalkilate.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: I suppose she's somewhat anxious about your father, and I dare say is expecting me to hurry.
speaker: the master

utterance: Oh, dad's all right. You'll come across him over yon, in the clearing. But you 're looking right purty with that gun. It kinder sets you off. You oughter wear one.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: Good-by.
speaker: the master

utterance: Your wife was sending you your rifle by Cressy, but I offered to bring it myself, as I thought it scarcely a proper errand for a young lady. Here it is. I hope you didn't miss it before and don't require it now.
speaker: the master

utterance: It's about half an hour late, but them Harrisons reckoned I was fixed for 'em and war too narvous to draw a clear bead on me.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: You are hurt, and here I am detaining you.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: I had my hand up- so, and the ball raked off my little finger after it went through my hat. But that ain't what I wanted to say when I stopped ye. I ain't just kam enough yet, and I clean forgit myself, But I was kalkilatin' to ask you -if Cressy kem all right?
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Perfectly. But shan't I walk on home with you, and we can talk together after your wound is attended to?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: And she looked purty?
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Very.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: And you thought them new store gownds of hers right peart?
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Yes. Perhaps a little too fine for the school, you know, and
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Not for her—not for her. I reckon thar's more whar that cam from! Ye need n't fear but that she kin keep up that gait ez long ez Hiram McKinstry hez the runnin' of her.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: At another time I'd like to have a long talk with you about your daughter, Mr. McKinstry.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Talk on. I admire to hear you. You 're that kam, it does me good.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: This is what I wished to say to Mrs. McKinstry to-day, but she referred me to you.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: In course, in course. She's a good woman in and around the ranch, and in any doin's o' this kind, there ain't a better, tho' I say it. She was Blair Rawlins' darter; she and her brother Clay bein' the only ones that kem out safe arter their twenty years' fight with the McEntees in West Kaintuck. But she don't understand gals ez you and me do. Not that I'm much, ez I orter be more kam. And the old woman jest sized the hull thing when she said she had n't any hand in Cressy's engagement. No more she had! And ez far ez that goes, no more did me, nor Seth Davis, nor Cressy.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Ye must n't mind my tellin' ye that the one - ez betwixt man and man - ez is most responsible for the makin' and breakin' o' that engagement is you!
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Me!
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: You! I ain't sayin' ye either know'd it or kalkilated on it. But it war so. Ef ye'd hark to me, and meander on a little, I'll tell ye how it war. I don't mind walkin' a piece your way, for if we go towards the ranch, and the hounds see me, they'll set up a racket and bring out the old woman, and then good-by to any confidential talk betwixt you and me. And I'm, somehow, kammer out yer.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: When you first kem to Injin Spring, Seth and Cressy was goin' to school, boy and girl like, and nothin' more. They'd known each other from babies - the Davises bein' our neighbors in Kaintuck, and emigraten' with us from St. Joe. Seth mout hev cottoned to Cress, and Cress to him, in course o' time, and there was n't anythin' betwixt the families to hev kept 'em from marryin' when they wanted. But there never war any words passed, and no engagement.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: But, my predecessor, Mr. Martin, distinctly told me that there was, and that it was with your permission.
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: That's only because you noticed suthin' the first day you looked over the school with Martin. Dad,' sez Cress to me, 'that new teacher 's very peart; and he's that keen about noticin' me and Seth that I reckon you'd better giv out that we're engaged.' 'But are you?' sez I. 'It'll come to that in the end,' sez Cress, and if that yer teacher hez come here with Northern ideas o' society, it's just ez well to let him see Injin Spring ain't entirely in the woods about them things. either. So I agreed, and Martin told you it was all right; Cress and Seth was an en- gaged couple, and you was to take no notice. And then you ups and objects to the hull thing, and allows that courtin' in school, even among engaged pupils, ain't proper.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Dad,' sez Cress to me, 'that new teacher 's very peart; and he's that keen about noticin' me and Seth that I reckon you'd better giv out that we're engaged.'
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: 'But are you?' sez I.
speaker: Hiram McKinstry

utterance: 'It'll come to that in the end,' sez Cress, and if that yer teacher hez come here with Northern ideas o' society, it's just ez well to let him see Injin Spring ain't entirely in the woods about them things.
speaker: Cressy McKinstry

utterance: I don't mind tellin' you, now that it's over, what happened. The trouble with me, Mr. Ford, is-I ain't kam! and you air, and that's what got me. For when I heard what you'd said, I got on that mustang and started for the school-house to clean you out and giv' you five minutes to leave Injin Spring. I don't know ez you remember that day. I'd kalkilated my time so ez to ketch ye comin' out o' school, but I was too airly. I hung around out o' sight, and then hitched my hoss to a buckeye and peeped inter the winder to hev a good look at ye. It was very quiet and kam. There was squirrels over the roof, yellow-jackets and bees dronin' away, and kinder sleeping-like all around in the air, and jay-birds twitterin' in the shin- gles, and they never minded me. You were movin' up and down among them little gals and boys, liftin' up their heads and talkin' to 'em softly and quiet like, ez if you was one of them yourself. And they looked contented and kam. And onct-I don't know if you remember it - you kem close up to the winder with your hands behind you, and looked out so kam and quiet and so far off, ez if everybody else outside the school was miles away from you. It kem to me then that I'd given a heap to hev had the old woman see you thar. It kem to me, Mr. Ford, that there was n't any place for me thar; and it kem to me, too and a little rough like that mebbee there was n't any place there for my Cress either! So I rode away without disturbin' you nor the birds nor the squirrels. Talkin' with Cress that night, she said ez how it was a fair sample of what happened every day, and that you'd always treated her fair like the others. So she allowed that she'd go down to Sacra mento, and get some things agin her and Seth bein' married next month, and she reckoned she would n't trouble you nor the school agin. Hark till I've done, Mr. Ford,
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: Well, I agreed. But arter she got to Sac- ramento and bought some fancy fixin's, she wrote to me and sez ez how she'd been thinkin' the hull thing over, and she reck- oned that she and Seth were too young to marry, and the engagement had better be broke. And I broke it for her.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: But how?
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Gin'rally with this gun, for I ain't kam. I let on to Seth's father that if I ever found Seth and Cressy together again, I'd shoot him. It made a sort o' coolness betwixt the families, and hez given some comfort to them low-down Harrisons; but even the law, I reckon, recognizes a father's rights. And ez Cress sez, now ez Seth's out o' the way, thar ain't no reason why she can't go back to school and finish her eddication. And I reckoned she was right. And we both agreed that ez she'd left school to git them store clothes, it was only fair that she 'd give the school the benefit of 'em.
speaker: McKinstry

utterance: But you are quite sure you won't regret that you did n't avail yourself of this broken engagement, and your daughter's outfit to send her to some larger boarding-school in Sacramento or San Francisco? Don't you think she may find it dull, and soon tire of the company of mere children when she has already known the excitement of
speaker: Mr. Ford

utterance: Mr. Ford, when I said just now that, lookin' inter that kam, peaceful school of yours, I didn't find a place for Cress, it war n't because I didn't think she oughter hev a place thar. Thar was that thar wot she never had ez a little girl with me and the old woman, and that she could n't find ez a grownd up girl in any boarding-school -the home of a child; that kind o' inno- cent foolishness that I sometimes reckon must hev slipped outer our emigrant wagon comin' across the plains, or got left behind at St. Joe. She was a grownd girl fit to marry afore she was a child. She had young fellers a-sparkin' her afore she ever played with 'em ez boy and girl. I don't mind tellin' you that it wer n't in the natur of Blair Rawlins' darter to teach her own darter any better, for all she's been a mighty help to me. So if it's all the same to you, Mr. Ford, we won't talk about a grownd up school; I'd rather Cress be a little girl again among them other children. I should be a powerful sight more kam if I knowed that when I was away huntin' stock or fightin' stakes with them Harrisons, that she was a settin' there with them and the birds and the bees, and listenin' to them and to you. Mebbee there's been a little too many scrimmages goin' on round the ranch sence she's been a child; mebbee she orter know suthin' more of a man than a feller who sparks her and fights for her.

It's natural she should feel a little ugly. We all do when we get sorter kicked back onto ourselves, and find we can't stand alone. Why, you wouldn't believe it, but the night I lost my little Rosey, of diphtheria in Gold Hill, the child was down on the bills for a comic song; and I had to drag Mrs. Sol on, cut up as she was, and filled up with that much of Old Bourbon to keep her nerves stiff, so she could do an old gag with me to gain time, and make up the 'variety.' Why, sir, when I came to the front, I was ugly! And when one of the boys in the front row sang out, 'Don't expose that poor child to the night air, Sol,'-meaning Mrs. Sol, I acted ugly. No, sir, it's human nature; and it was quite natural that Mornie, when she caught sight o' Mrs. Sol's face last night, should rise up and cuss us both. Lord, if she'd only acted like that!
